ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: D3.js, theories about visualization, other people's research.
How to develop visualizations from scratch using d3.js.
Learned about data visualization concepts as well as how to program with the JavaScript library d3.
I have learned how to use JavaScript, HTML, and what constitutes a good or bad visualization.
This course had so much memorization of subjects that won't be useful for me.
Learned how to make visualizations with D3 and learned some principles about visualization.
How to use D3 (and a surprisingly large amount of knowledge on UIUX)!
I learned a lot about visualization generally, and gained skills with D3 for vis on the web.
I gained an understanding of the theory behind data visualizations  specifically what visualizations are composed of and how they are made.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of this class is a large chunk of its grade is hands-on d3.js project, so at the bare minimum you would practice coding in JavaScript. However, this class spends too much time on abstract visualization theories, which is not relevant to the practice of creating visualization. Personally, I couldn't pay attention in class, and it seems like not many other people were.

Strengths: Professor Rushmeier's teaching style, structure in PSETs and lectures
Weaknesses: Exams sometimes tested nitpicky memorization rather than critical thinking

The lectures/readings can be a bit dry at times just because they are a lot of information. I come from a design background so some of the theory is very interesting, while some of it is not as exciting to me. Also I don't really think the memorization based midterm and final are a good assessment of engagement and learning in the course (it's just going through the slides and trying to memorize everything, and coding on paper which to me does not really make sense).
The textbook and lectures from this course were very helpful and explained well.
I believe using another programming language instead of javascript would be a great improvement in this course.

strengths:
- great instructor, great TA.
- not too big a workload, just start on the assignments early and if you're stuck, go to office hours once and you'll get all your problems fixed.
- first half of the course (before the midterm) is interesting

weaknesses:
- second half of the course (after the midterm) is a bit disjoint and harder to follow. the topics become much more abstract and complex and aren't really elaborated on in lecture
- the coding assignments are completely disconnected to what you learn in class. so like, you'll be learning a bunch of conceptual stuff and then a coding assignment will pretty have nothing to do with that. it's fine for the most part but would have loved some more guidance on the D3 coding.

Strengths: You learn how to display complex data in more accessible ways and about basic UI/UX principles. 

Weaknesses: the exams felt incredibly arbitrary and always tested on the nichest knowledge, which often felt irrelevant to what we were doing for PSets (and what most people probably would be building in the future).
The contents of the lectures are comprehensive and covered aspects of visualization in a super structured way. The assignments are incremental and works along with concepts taught in class.

The course has a focus on memorization of random facts that are tangentially related to visualizations. There is little focus on how to code with D3, and even less on what the best D3 practices are for coding, such as style.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, even though Professor Rushmeier is a very kind and helpful person, and I respect her greatly, I cannot in good conscience recommend this class. To be honest, I came into this class expecting it to be a gut. It isn't, so if you are looking for a gut, this is wrong place to go to. Each visualization assignment takes a long time to do, and the two midterms require fact-based recall of at least 100 entries of facts each, which is another time sink. It would be justified if these concepts were actually relevant. They are not. They are very abstract, academic theories about data visualization that might be useful if you are interested in doing meta-research about visualization, but are not useful for any kind of practical applications. To give a specific instance (to illustrate the absurdity of some of the facts we were asked to remember), we were asked to recall the name of a person (who is not even particularly famous) who created a specific visualization at a specific event in the twentieth century. I don't understand why remembering facts like these is conducive to anyone's learning. As another example, we were asked to recall what three guest lecturers each specifically talked about in their presentations. It almost feels like the class is structured around taking attendance, such that the purpose of the exam is also to check attendance. Indeed, on each lecture attendance is taken, and you cannot even miss more than 4 lectures even if many of them you will find convey little meaningful information. Data visualization is great, but you should learn it elsewhere. Please do not take this class.
Yes  if they were interested in learning the basics of visualization design and theory.

It is somewhat of an interesting course but can be pretty dry at times -- the workload is pretty manageable though so that's a pretty big reason to take it. The exams are just a bit rough but if you manage to study a bit each week you'd probably be better off.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in computer science.
No.

Yes. Highly recommend as a CS elective. not a heavy work load at all, super manageable. Definitely take this course because Prof Rushmeier is the best. it's also nice to learn how to make some cool visualizations
I would only recommend this course to other students if they are interested in UI/UX and have not had the opportunity to take Intro to HCL, or are interested in displaying complex data.
Yes, definitely for students interested in visualization. this works great as an intro level course to this topic.
